chapter: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question:
Question 1: A 29-year-old African American man receives primaquine chemoprophylaxis before traveling 
for a business trip. Four days later, he presents with jaundice and dark urine. Laboratory 
investigations show anemia, reticulocytosis, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The 
peripheral blood smear shows the presence of Heinz bodies. What is the most likely mode of 
inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history suggestive of hemolysis after the antimalarial (primaquine) and Heinz 
bodies on PBF, points to a diagnosis of G6PD deficiency (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase 
deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. G6PD is an enzyme belonging to the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway. Deficiency of 
enzymes of this pathway causes hemolysis as the protective ability of RBCs from oxidative stress is 
impaired. The image given below shows the Heinz bodies seen on peripheral smear. 402 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following is the most common trigger for hemolysis in patients with G6PD 
deficiency?
questions.explanation:
The most common trigger for hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is infection. Viral hepatitis, 
pneumonia, and typhoid are the common infections that trigger hemolysis. Episodic hemolysis (both intravascular and extravascular) is seen in G6PD deficiency. It is due to 
exposures that cause oxidative stress. The triggers include: • Infections - oxygen-derived free radicals produced by activated leukocytes • Drugs • Antimalarials - primaquine and chloroquine • Sulfonamides • Nitrofurantoin • Diet - fava bean
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question:
Question 3: Peripheral smear of a patient with viral hepatitis is given below. Which of the following 
statements is false about this finding? 398 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: These are seen in G6PD deficiency
options.b: They are due to denaturation of globin chains
options.c: They are plucked out by macrophages in the spleen
options.d: They do not cause intravascular hemolysis

questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear shows Heinz bodies which are dark stained inclusion bodies in red 
cells. They can cause intravascular as well as extravascular hemolysis. In G6PD-deficiency, the RBCs are exposed to high levels of oxidants. This causes cross-linking of 
reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. The globin chains become denatured and form 
membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These can be detected by supravital 
staining. Heinz bodies can damage the membrane sufficiently to cause intravascular hemolysis. 403 
Sold by @itachibot As RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen, the macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies. 
As a result, some of these partially devoured cells retain an abnormal shape i.e. as if a bite was 
taken out of them. Such cells are called bite cells. Bite cells are trapped in splenic cords and 
removed by phagocytes leading to extravascular hemolysis. The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency. 404 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with G6PD deficiency was suspected to have acute hemolytic episode. Which of the 
following features would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Acute hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is intravascular. This is marked by anaemia, 
hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria. These episodes are self-limited and intermittent. Reticulocytosis occurs during the recovery phase. 
Hence, features related to chronic hemolysis (e.g., splenomegaly, cholelithiasis) are absent.
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question:
Question 5: A 23-year-old food blogger presents with complaints of icterus and abdominal fullness. She 
returned yesterday from a vacation in Egypt where she tried fava beans. Her peripheral smear 
is given below. This condition is protective against which of the following malarial parasites? 399 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The peripheral smear shows RBCs with anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia and many bite 
cells (arrows) suggestive of G6PD deficiency. This condition is protective against Plasmodium 405 
Sold by @itachibot falciparum malaria. Malarial parasites preferentially invade RBCs which are rich in G6PD. G6PD deficiency causes 
oxidative stress and hemolysis, preferably in the older RBCs. Reticulocytes and young 
erythrocytes have much higher G6PD activities and are less susceptible to oxidant damage. P. falciparum can invade erythrocytes of all ages. P. vivax, and P. ovale invade reticulocytes 
(immature erythrocytes) preferentially. Hence, a low G6PD level in older RBC is protective against 
P. falciparum malaria. Episodic hemolysis in this condition can be triggered by fava beans which is a staple in Egyptian 
cuisine. The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is not true about G6PD-deficiency anemia?

options.a: Hemolytic episodes occur both intravascularly and extravascularly
options.b: G6PD Mediterranean deficiency is the most severe form.
options.c: Older RBCs are more prone to hemolysis than younger ones
options.d: Hemolysis continues as long as there is exposure to oxidant drugs

questions.explanation:
406 
Sold by @itachibot Hemolysis in G6PD-deficiency anemia does not continue for the entire period that the patient 
takes the offending drug. It stops after a few days. Two variants of G6PD, designated as G6PD– and G6PD Mediterranean, cause most of the 
clinically significant hemolytic anemias. The half-life of G6PD- is moderately reduced, whereas 
that of G6PD Mediterranean is markedly reduced; hence, the severity of deficiency is greater with 
the Mediterranean variant. The most common normal variant is G6PD B. The hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. The 
damaged red cells are sequestered in the spleen and killed 
by macrophages, causing extravascular hemolysis. The oxidative stresses can denature 
hemoglobin, resulting in intravascular hemolysis. In individuals with G6PD deficiency, acute intravascular hemolysis begins 2 to 3 days after 
exposure to oxidants. Only older RBCs are at risk for lysis. The hemolytic episode is 
self-limited because hemolysis stops when only younger G6PD-replete red cells remain, even if the 
patient continues to take the offending drug.
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question:
Question 7: What class of antibodies are involved in the most common form of immunohemolytic 
anaemia?
questions.explanation:
Warm antibody type is the most common form of immunohemolytic anaemia. Most of the 
causative antibodies in this condition belong to the IgG class. Immunohemolytic anaemia is caused by antibodies that cause premature destruction of the red 
cells. Based on the temperature at which the different types of antibodies bind to the RBCs stably, 
they are classified as: • Warm antibody type - most common • Cold agglutinin type • Cold hemolysin type
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question: Question 8: Match the immunohemolytic anaemia with the type of hemolysis.
questions.explanation:
The type of hemolysis seen in the different immunohemolytic anemia are: Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (AIHA) cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. In warm antibody type, hemolysis is extravascular. IgG-coated red cells are phagocytosed and 
destroyed in the spleen. In cold agglutinin type, hemolysis is extravascular and intravascular. In the peripheral vascular 
bed (low temperature), IgM binds to the red cells. This causes agglutination and 
complement-fixing. They are unbound when they reach the general circulation. However, the IgM 
interaction causes deposition of sublytic quantities of C3b. It is an excellent opsonin, which leads 
to the removal of RBCs by phagocytes in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Cold hemolysin type is a rare subtype of AIHA. Hemolysis is intravascular. IgG binds to the P 
blood group antigen on the red cells, which leads to complement-mediated lysis. 407

questions.question:
Question 9: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with loss of consciousness. On 
examination, pallor, icterus and splenomegaly were noted. Her past history was significant 
for meningitis 2 weeks ago which was treated with iv antibiotics. Lab investigations showed 
anemia and increased osmotic fragility. Which of the following statements is false regarding 
the probable diagnosis?

options.a: Rh blood group complex are involved in the pathogenesis
options.c: Direct Coombs agglutination test is diagnostic

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced warm antibody type of immunohemolytic 
anemia. In this condition, primarily extravascular hemolysis is present. LDH may be increased 
when there is hemolysis. Two different mechanisms for drug-induced immune hemolytic anemias are: Antigenic drugs: • Anemia occurs 1-2 weeks after initiation of large IV dose of the offending drug • These drugs bind to red cell membrane and are recognised by anti-drug antibodies • They can cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis • E.g. penicillin, cephalosporins, quinidine Tolerance-breaking drugs: • Antibodies are produced against red cell antigens, particularly Rh antigens • E.g. alpha-methyl dopa
questions.chapter_heading: G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is false about paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria?

options.a: IgG class of antibodies are involved
options.b: Antibodies are directed against Rh antigen
options.d: It mostly occurs in children following a viral infection

questions.explanation:
In paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH), antibodies are directed against the P blood group 
antigen. PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies classically. They are also 
called Donath Landsteiner antibodies and are produced often in response to a viral infection. This 
antibody is a biphasic hemolysin. i.e., the antibody binds to RBC at colder temperature but 
hemolysis occurs at core temperature 37°C. This can cause substantial, sometimes fatal, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Most 
cases are seen in children following viral infections and usually recover within 1 month. Immuno-hemolytic anaemias are of 3 types: 408

questions.question:
Question 11: In which of the following conditions is microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia most commonly 
seen?
questions.explanation:
Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia is most commonly seen with disseminated intravascular 
coagulation. It occurs in the following conditions: • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) • Malignant hypertension • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Disseminated cancer A common pathogenic feature in these disorders is a microvascular lesion. Deposition of fibrin 
and platelets result in luminal narrowing. These vascular changes produce shear stresses. These 
changes mechanically injure the passing red cells producing schistocytes or helmet cells on the 
peripheral smear. The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells. 409
